options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: we studied 12 of the most famous/influential trials in US history, including the facts, surrounding events, and lasting legacy

This course gives a historical overview of the most influential 20th Century United States court cases. The themes of these cases include: Celebrity, Race, Politics, and many more. In addition, Professor Ford gives instruction into basic concepts regarding the justice system, Constitutional law, and proceedings that take place in a courtroom.
I learned about various court cases throughout the 20th century as well as how to carefully consider all perspectives underlying court decisions.
I learned how to think about court cases and the law in the context of time, place and celebrity. Thus, I also learned about times in American history.
Such a relevant course to discuss issues that still exist in our society today and the progress they have made through the justice system

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Honestly this is a great course and there isn't much that I would change about it.

Strengths - Professor Ford is a gem, he's so kind and knowledgeable

Weakness - Professor Ford also talks most of the time

Prof. Ford is really amazing. He is super knowledgable and really engages with the students. The seminar format is great for learning and discussing the cases in detail and I really enjoyed these discussions and felt they facilitated learning well.
Professor Ford was very knowledgeable, had great stories to share, and was very willing to chat with students about both the course materials and beyond!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom seminar was actually very fruitful and effective, even though I didn't expect it to be!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: ABSOLUTELY! If you can get in this course - take it. It is definitely my favorite course I have taken at Yale for many reasons: the teacher, the topic/content, the work itself. Some of the classes get to be a bit long, and there are a decent amount of readings, but it is such a fascinating class. I couldn't say enough positive things about Professor Ford; he has so many amazing stories to tell that make the class really worthwhile and different from any other class that I have ever taken at Yale.
Yes this is a great class

I would strongly recommend this course to another student at Yale, especially if they are a Senior who has never taken a Residential College seminar. Not only does this course look thoroughly at the "Trials of the Century", but it is also a great opportunity to learn about basic legal proceedings in the courtroom. While there were pre-Law students who knew more about the justice system, Professor Ford did a wonderful job of explaining this legal jargon to those who were unfamiliar. This course exceeded all expectations I had going into my final semester. I would definitely recommend this course to any and all students to try and take before they graduate from Yale!
YES! Take this course if you can! Professor Ford is an absolute GEM. His rich background as a journalist and prosecutor makes this class so interesting.
I consider this a must-take at yale. So many topics I always wanted to learn that I finally got to learn
Yes
Yes!!! Very interesting court cases
Absolutely! Amazing way to learn about trials which have set great precedents and have been famous throughout history.
10000000000% it is the best class I have taken at Yale. Professor Ford is so awesome, knowledgeable, and personable. If you are lucky enough to get a spot in this class absolutely take it

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom seminar
